introduction.p: The equations resulting from the application of Faraday's loop rule to an AC circuit results in the summation of sine and cosine functions. These calculations using the trigonometric functions are usually messy and an alternative method is desirable. It turns out that the algebra of complex numbers is better at these calculations than the sine and cosine functions.

The connection between complex analysis and sines and cosines comes from Euler's formula
e^{i\theta} = \cos\,\theta + i\,\sin\,\theta,
where i = \sqrt{-1}. Here, \cos\,\theta is the real part of e^{i\theta} and \sin\,\theta is the imaginary part of e^{i\theta}.
Thus, in AC circuit calculations, we replace the cosine of the source voltage by a complex exponential. Then, we perform regular algebra. After completing the calculations, the real part of the final result corresponds to the answer we seek.

To distinguish complex voltage representing a real voltage, we will use the same symbol, but place a tilde (~) sign above the symbol, and similarly for currents. Thus, we will replace
V = V_0\,\cos(\omega t + \phi)
by
\tilde V = V_0\, e^{ i ( \omega t + \phi ) },
whose real part is the original real voltage. As a result, the complex voltage \tilde{V} across an element and complex current \tilde{I} through it, are related by a complex version of Ohm's law, we can call Complex Ohm's Law.
\tilde{V} = \tilde{Z} \tilde{I},
where the complex resistance denoted by \tilde{Z} is called the impedance or the complex impedance of the element. In the following we will work out expressions for complex impedances of resistor, inductor and capacitor. We will find that complex impedance of inductor and capacitor are imaginary with absolute values equal to their reactances.

The inverse of the impedance is called admittance and is denoted by \tilde{Y}.
\tilde{Y} =\frac{1}{\tilde{Z}}.
We will see that the complex impedance allows one to treat resistors, capacitors and inductors in an AC circuit on an equal footing.

subsection.title: Rectangular and Polar Forms of Complex Numbers
subsection.p: You may already know that a complex number has two parts and can be written using i=\sqrt{-1}. For instance, 3+i4 is a complex part whose real part is 3 and imaginary part 4. This is called complex number written in rectangular or Cartesian form. You can imagine this as point (3,4) in a complex plane. You can think of complex plane as Cartesina xy-plane.

Just as you can represent a point in xy-pane by (x,y) coordinates or corresponding polar coordinates (r,\theta), you can do the same with a complex number. Thus, number 3+i4 will have polar representation re^{i\theta} with
r = \sqrt{3^2 + 4^2} = 5,\ \ \theta=\tan^{-1}\left( 4/3\right) = 51^\circ.
We call r absolute value or amplitude of the complex number x+iy and \theta phase of the complex number. Suppose, we denote complex number x+iy by letter z. Then, we will often write its r as
r = |z|.
For instance, absolute value of complex impedance is equal to the amplitude of the impedance we have defined above.
|Z| = |\tilde{Z}|.
Also, note that absolute value of a complex number with r=1 will be 1. That is, if a complex number is purely exponential, i.e, if z=e^{i\theta}, then
|z| = \left| z=e^{i\theta} \right| = 1.
Yoou can immediately verify this by using Euler's formula given above and \cos^2\theta + \sin^2\theta = 1.

subsection.title: Complex Impedance of a Resistor
subsection.p:
Since current I(t) through a resistor and V_R(t), the voltage drop across a resistor are in-phase, when we take their ratio to get impedance, the exponetials will cancel out, leaving just the real resistance R.
\tilde{Z}_R = \dfrac{\tilde{V}_R}{\tilde{I}} = R.

subsection.title: Complex Impedance of an Inductor
subsection.p:
Since current V_L(t) across an inductor leads current I(t) through it by a phase of \pi/2 radians, their ratio will give reactance times an exponential with a positive phase constant.
\tilde{Z}_L = \dfrac{\tilde{V}_L}{\tilde{I}} = \omega L e^{i\pi/2} = i \omega L,
where I used e^{i \pi/2} = \cos\, \pi/2 + i\, \sin\, \pi/2 = 0 + i = i. Note that absolute value of this impedance is the expected reactance of the inductor.
|Z_L| = \omega L.
The phase of complex Z_L is \frac{\pi}{2}.

subsection.title: Complex Impedance of a Capacitor
subsection.p:
Since current V_L(t) across a capacitor lags current I(t) through it by a phase of \pi/2 radians, their ratio will give reactance times an exponential with a negative phase constant.
\tilde{Z}_C = \dfrac{\tilde{V}_C}{\tilde{I}} = \dfrac{1}{\omega C} e^{-i\pi/2} = i \omega L,
where I used e^{i \pi/2} = \cos\, \pi/2 - i\, \sin\, \pi/2 = 0 - i = - i. Note that absolute value of this impedance is the expected reactance of the capacitor.
|Z_C| = \dfrac{1}{\omega C}.
The phase of complex Z_C is -\frac{\pi}{2}.

subsection.title: AC Circuit Problems
subsection.p: The first step in the analysis of an AC circuit is to replace circuit elements by their impedances. Each resistor R is replaced by its Z_R = R, each inductance L is replaced by its impedance Z_L = i\omega L, and each capacitance is replaced by its impedance Z_C =1/ i\omega C. Then, we subject the circuit by Kirchoff's current law for complexe currents and Faraday's loop rule for each loop in the circuit. We then, solve for complex currents and deduce the physical currents from the real parts of the complex currents. These steps are best illustrated by examples.

example.title: Series RLC Circuit in Complex Notation

statement.p: Consider the series RLC-circuit. Find current in the circuit.

figure.caption: A series RLC-circuit driven by an alternating EMF.

hint.p: Replace passive circuit elements by their complex impedances and treat them as resistors.

answer.p: I_0 = \dfrac{V_0}{ \sqrt{ R^2 + \left( \omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\right)^2 } }, \phi_I = - \tan^{-1} \left( \dfrac{\omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}}{R} \right).

solution.p: First step in our solution is to replace original circuit by a complex circuit where we replace R by Z_R, C by Z_C, and L by Z_L, and treat currents and voltages complex. This is shown as a complex circuit in the figure below.

figure.caption: A series RLC-circuit driven by an alternating EMF with complex quantities.

solution.p:
Now, we think of impedances as if they were simple resistors. In this circuit, the loop equation will give
\tilde V - \tilde Z_R\tilde I - \tilde Z_L\tilde I - \tilde Z_C\tilde I = 0,
which can be solved for complex current.
\tilde I = \dfrac{\tilde V}{ \tilde Z_R + \tilde Z_L + \tilde Z_C}.
From this we note that complex impedance of the circuit is
\tilde Z \amp = \tilde Z_R + \tilde Z_L + \tilde Z_C \amp = R + i \omega L+ \dfrac{-i}{\omega C} \amp = R + i \left( \omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\right)
This is rectangular form of complex impedance, which we can also write in polar form. Let
R + i \left( \omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\right) = |Z|\,e^{i\phi_Z}.
Then,
|Z| = \sqrt{ R^2 + \left( \omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\right)^2 } \phi_Z = \tan^{-1} \left( \dfrac{\omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}}{R} \right)
Using polar form of complex impedance in Eq. we get polar form of complex current.
\tilde I = \dfrac{\tilde V}{ \tilde Z } = \dfrac{V_0}{|Z|}\, e^{i\left(\omega t-\phi_Z\right)},
whose real part gives the physical current in the circuit.
I(t) = \dfrac{V_0}{|Z|}\,\cos(\omega t - \phi_Z ).
Wrting this as I(t) = I_0\,\cos(\omega t + \phi_I) we have
I_0 = \dfrac{V_0}{ \sqrt{ R^2 + \left( \omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\right)^2 } }, \phi_I = - \tan^{-1} \left( \dfrac{\omega L- \dfrac{1}{\omega C}}{R} \right).

example.title: Parallel RL Circuit in Complex Notation

statement.p: Consider the circuit given in the Fig. \ref{fig:example-ac-RL-1} where a resistor R and an inductor L are connected in parallel to an AC power generator with voltage V(t) = V_0\cos(\omega t). Find (a) current in each branch of the circuit, (b) average power dissipated in the resistor, and (c) average power produced by the AC generator.

figure.caption: A parallel RL-circuit driven by an alternating EMF.

hint.p: Replace passive circuit elements by their complex impedances and treat them as resistors.

answer.p: (a) I_1(t) = \dfrac{V_0}{R}\,\cos(\omega t), I_2(t) = \dfrac{V_0}{\omega L}\,\sin(\omega t), I = I_1 + I_2, (b) and (c) \dfrac{1}{2}\,\dfrac{V_0^2}{R}

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: (a) First step in our solution is to replace original circuit by a complex circuit where we replace R by Z_R, and L by Z_L, and treat currents and voltages complex. This is shown as a complex circuit in the figure below.

figure.caption: A parallel RL-circuit driven by an alternating EMF with complex quantities.

solution.p:
From loop with source and \tilde Z_R we get
\tilde I_1 = \dfrac{\tilde V}{\tilde Z_R} = \dfrac{V_0}{R}\, e^{i\omega t},
whose real part gives the physical current through R.
I_1(t) = \dfrac{V_0}{R}\,\cos(\omega t).

From loop with source and \tilde Z_L we get
\tilde I_2 = \dfrac{\tilde V}{\tilde Z_L} = \dfrac{V_0}{i\omega L}\, e^{i\omega t},
whose real part gives the physical current through L. To obtain the real part of this complex quantity we note that
\dfrac{1}{i} = -i = e^{-i\pi/2},
which can be combined with e^{i\omega t} to give
\tilde I_2 = \dfrac{V_0}{\omega L}\, e^{i(\omega t - \pi/2)},
whose real part is
I_2(t) = \dfrac{V_0}{\omega L}\,\cos(\omega t -\pi/2),
which we can also write as
I_2(t) = \dfrac{V_0}{\omega L}\,\sin(\omega t),
Conservation of current at nodes gives the overall current.
I(t) \amp = I_1(t) + I_2(t) \amp = \dfrac{V_0}{R}\,\cos(\omega t) + \dfrac{V_0}{\omega L}\,\sin(\omega t).
We can write this answer as I_0\,\cos(\omega t + \phi_I) with the following answer.
I_0 = V_0\,\sqrt{ \left( \dfrac{1}{R} \right)^2 + \left( \dfrac{1}{\omega L} \right)^2 }, \phi_I = -\tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{R}{\omega L}\right).
To see these expressions, you can either expand I_0\,\cos(\omega t + \phi_I), equate the result to the answer in Eq. , separately equate coefficients of \cos(\omega t) and \sin(\omega t), and then solve for the phase constant and amplitude.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The instantaneous power dissipated in the resistor will be
P_R(t) = I_1(t) V_R(t) = R I_1(t)^2 = R \left( \dfrac{V_0}{R}\right)^2\,\cos^2(\omega t).
Average of \cos^2(\omega t) is \dfrac{1}{2}. Therefore, average power dissipates is
P_{R,\text{av}} \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}\,\dfrac{V_0^2}{R}.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) The instantaneous power delivered to the circuit by the source will be
P(t) = I(t) V(t) = I_0 V_0 \cos(\omega t) \cos(\omega t + \phi_I)
Average of \cos(\omega t) \cos(\omega t + \phi_I) is \dfrac{1}{2}\cos\,\phi_I. Therefore, average power dissipates is
P_{\text{av}} \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}\,I_0 V_0\cos\,\phi_I, \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}\, \left[V_0\sqrt{\left( \dfrac{1}{R} \right)^2 + \left( \dfrac{1}{\omega L} \right)^2 }\right]\, V_0\, \left[\dfrac{\omega L}{\sqrt{R^2 + \omega^2 L^2}}\right]. \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}\,\dfrac{V_0^2}{R}.
This is the same as the energy dissipated in the resistor, the only place where energy could have gone.

example.title: Circuit Elements in Series and in Parallel

statement.p:
(a) Find current through the capacitor in the circuit. (b) Use the following values to find the numerical values of the magnitude and phase of the current through the capacior.
\amp V_0=170\text{ V},\ \ \omega = 2\pi\times 60\text{ sec}^{-1}, \amp R = 1000\ \Omega;\ \ L = 1\; \text{mH};\ \ C = 1\; \mu\text{F}.

hint.p: Replace passive circuit elements by their complex impedances and treat them as resistors.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: (a) We start by first replacing the passive elements in the circuit by their impedances.

Since we just want the current through C, which is the same as current through the source, we will work out equivalent impedance of everything connected across the source. We see that \tilde{Z}_C is in series with parallel combinations of \tilde{Z}_R and \tilde{Z}_L, the equivalent impedance is
\tilde{Z} \amp = \tilde{Z}_C + \left( \dfrac{1}{\tilde{Z}_R} + \dfrac{1}{\tilde{Z}_L} \right)^{-1}, \amp = \dfrac{-i}{\omega C} + \left( \dfrac{1}{R} + \dfrac{1}{i\omega L} \right)^{-1}, \amp = \dfrac{-i}{\omega C} + \dfrac{i\omega R L}{ R + i\omega L } , \amp = \dfrac{-i}{\omega C} + \dfrac{i\omega R L}{ R + i\omega L }\times \dfrac{R-i\omega L}{R-i\omega L}, \amp = \dfrac{\omega^2 R L^2}{ R^2 + \omega^2 L^2 } + i \left(\dfrac{\omega R^2 L}{ R^2 + \omega^2 L^2 } - \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\right).
This gives real and imaginary parts of the equivalent complex impedance.
\amp \text{Re}(Z) = \dfrac{\omega^2 R L^2}{ R^2 + \omega^2 L^2 } \equiv a, \amp \text{Im}(Z) = \dfrac{\omega R^2 L}{ R^2 + \omega^2 L^2 } - \dfrac{1}{\omega C} \equiv b.
Therefore, we have Z = |Z|e^{i\phi_Z} with
\amp |Z| = \sqrt{a^2 + b^2}, \amp \phi_Z = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{b}{a}\right).
Using the magnitude and phase of equivalent impedance, we can immediately write the magnitude and phase of current through the course, I = I_0\cos(\omega t + \phi_I), with
\amp I_0 = V_0/|Z|, \amp \phi_I = -\phi_Z.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b)
The value of impedances of the elements are:
Z_R = 1000\; \Omega;\ \ Z_L = i 0. 377\; \Omega; \ \ Z_C =-i 2652\; \Omega.
The equivalent impedance becomes
\tilde{Z} \approx 1.4\times 10^{-4} \Omega - i 2652 \Omega.
The amplitudes and phase of the current would be,
I_0 \approx 64\; \text{mA}.
\phi_I \approx \frac{\pi}{2}\; \text{rad}.
